author: lamax6
title: Pull Over!!
review: Great little set.  All three of mine do a great job patrolling the town and the airport on the outskirts of town.  I got rid of the white lightbar, and instead placed a 1x2 black plate on the roof to separate the lights.

author: folkform
title: Classic goodness
review: This was my first ever lego set, so I feel like I should give it a perfect score.  It is well constructed and is great to play with.  However, it is a bit too plain, even for 1984 standards--the front needs something more than just the headlights to designate from the back.

author: hustla187
title: Best Police Car Possible!
review: Lego did a great job on making cars like these back in the 1980's. I really like the detail put into this set and yet it is still fun to play with. The double sirens are very cool and gives it a nice touch. This set is really good and must be rereleased.

author: Skut
title: A town classic
review: This set uses the best ever car design from Lego - appearing in a number of sets - and puts it in a Police car format. While there may have been some quicker looking cars over the years, there has never been a better cruiser for your officers to patrol your town! Also blends very nicely with the "classic" Police stations released through the 80s.

author: legotowner
title: Legotown Patrol Car - did the job well
review:
This was one of my first sets, not sure what was my first I cant remember, but this was probably my early favourite when I started buliding and playing aged 3 or 4.

The car was simple, looked like a police car with a good looking policeman and had speed. The base of the car could be used to make other cars but the police setup was good enough and replaced the jeep from 6386 garage when it was built.

Unfortunately the car was taken to the wreckers when the base plate split in two, it could still be built but the structural integrity had been comprimised for high speed chases.

author: jsosse
title: Feels like riding a Lada
review:
Do you know what a Lada Laika is? If you do, you know what I mean with the title above... Is just the best example of "kid's drawing car": just a boxy little thing with wheels that goes around as being a car...

Not different for Lego. This set could be way more interesting, regardless of it being released in a time when Lego vehicles were more intended to be playable with than to look real (no problem with that, either). I won't recall the sets numbers, but you can look them up as an example that good cars COULD be done at the time this patrol car first went to store:

Highway maintenance truck
Postal truck
Octan tanker
etc. etc...

author: CamberbrickGreen
title: The Chief Of Police
review:
A review barely seems necessary for the blatant appeal and manifest worth.

Minifigures:
  • Yep, its thats shirt, trousers and cap again but is this one the chief?

Patrol Car

Yes it really is a great and well loved oldie. If as a child, you even slightly liked the societal powerful presence of the Police Force with their flashing blue lights and fast white cars then this set was an inevitable choice.

Its a fine build with good parts and is very useable as a trouble magnet or the pursuer of wrong-doers. You could place preference with similar cars in larger sets- the one with the same era Police Station has more black and obviously comes with a large building, vehicles and staff. As Town cars go, they do not get much better just more flashy so for a proper Town or City layout, this Police Car is worth owning in some form before flash modern emergency sets dominate the subconscious.

This set seems representative of the Police subtheme for its time so what are other years subthemes iconic sets? The 6629 ambulance? Beyond personal choices some sets will always prove more popular but this one seems warranted beyond childhood police obsessions!

With Emergency Service sets in high supply and money in short supply, some collection options arise:
  • Collect one large set.
  • Collect all sets from one year or 'era'.
  • Keep the favourite from each service subtheme and sell the rest?!
Emergency service set obsession can slightly disturb. Recent sets have gone totally ballistic, with all manner of semi-futurism. We must regard public service people as literally the most important in civilisation for their continued popularity in miniature plastic incarnation. I respect new era and generation sets but not so much for the 999/911 themes due to their design philosophy: bigger, brighter, more, ad infinitum. However a disaster scenario each year could provide solid design requirements for sets and 2012 seems very interesting as they seem to have changed tack and are trying something different; an inventive forest theme...if forgivably bigger, brighter and more!

Law Wagon
The old cop car here is a natural choice for the Town Police collector and will forever be the cop car for any Town traffic feature.

author: CharmCityBrick
title: First LEGO set
review: So why do I give this set 5 Stars...This was my first ever Lego set, which I still have all 3 copies of it today and it is what started it all for me.  I still look at this set as perfect in its simplicity and imagination.  I love it!

author: goldenbane
title: A fun little set for a kid
review: I used to have this set when I was a little guy.  I probably could still cobble together the pieces and rebuild it, but I'm not interested at this time.  It was a very simple set to own, but pretty fun.  It's better if you have other sets for it to interact with.  Pretty solid little police car set, but nothing outstanding.
